html:
• U.S. equity indexes rise; Nov UMICH Sentiment < estimate
  • Materials lead S&P sector gainers; cons disc weakest group
  • Euro STOXX 600 index up ~0.2%
  • Dollar ~flat; gold, crude, bitcoin down
  • U.S. 10-Year Treasury yield ~1.56%

Nov 12 - Welcome to the home for real-time coverage of markets brought to you by Reuters reporters. You can share your thoughts with us at markets.research@thomsonreuters.com


U.S. STOCKS ADVANCE, BUT HEADED FOR WEEKLY LOSSES (0955 EST/1455 GMT)

U.S. stock indexes are higher early on Friday, led by Johnson & Johnson and big technology stocks in a week undermined by mounting fears about persistently high inflation.

That said, Wall Street's main indexes are on pace for weekly declines of more than 1%, for the first time since early October, as hotter-than-expected U.S. inflation readings weighed on market sentiment and derailed an earnings-driven streak of record closing highs.

Johnson & Johnson JNJ.N shares rose early Friday after the company said it plans to break up into two companies focused on its consumer health business and the large pharmaceuticals unit.

Shares of mega-cap technology and communication stocks including Google-owner Alphabet Inc GOOGL.O, Microsoft Corp MSFT.O, Meta Platforms Inc FB.O, formerly known as Facebook, Apple Inc AAPL.O and Amazon.com AMZN.O are all trading higher.

Here is a snapshot of U.S. stocks in early trading:

(Gertrude Chavez-Dreyfuss)

*****


WHAT'S EATING TURKEYS? (0923 EST/1423 GMT)

As Commerzbank FX strategists put it shortly after the U.S. inflation shocker on Wednesday, "Americans will probably have to dig deeper into their pockets this year for the Thanksgiving turkey at the end of November".

But how much more really?

BofA looked into this burning (preferably roasted or deep-fried) issue and came up with 25%:



But while Americans may have anxieties about their Thanksgiving meals, the same anguish is palpable in Britain in the run up to Christmas when millions of these birds will be consumed.

Susannah Streeter, an analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown took a look at data from the UK's statistics office and had alarming news.

"The latest snapshot of our shopping habits from the ONS shows that the meat was the item most often recorded as being in short supply in supermarkets up and down the UK over the last week", she wrote in a note.

"The birds are flying out of the deep freeze, faster than supermarkets can stock up again", she warned.


(Julien Ponthus and Karin Strohecker)

*****


NASDAQ COMPOSITE: CHANNEL SWIM ABOUT TO TURN ROUGH? (0845 EST/1345 GMT)

The Nasdaq Composite .IXIC was recently sailing along. Into its 15,982.357 November 8 close, the tech-laden index posted a run of 11-straight up-days, including eight-straight record finishes. Those were its longest such streaks since 11 and 10-day runs in December 2019.

With its recent rally to an intraday high of 16,053.386, the Composite nearly tagged a monthly log-scale channel resistance parallel, which in November resides around 16,300. This hurdle is based off of a support line drawn from the 2009 low:



The IXIC then fell back more than 3% in just three trading days. Of note, upon nearly tagging this line in March and again in September, the Composite promptly suffered declines of nearly 13% and 8%, so it appears to be a formidable barrier.

Meanwhile, monthly momentum is lagging. Although the RSI is rising from its September, it remains shy of its August high, despite the Nasdaq's fresh records.

Just looking back to late 2018, a number of severe Nasdaq sell offs were preceded by multi-month momentum divergence.

Therefore, traders may be on guard for an RSI down-tick as it could solidify the divergence. In the event, the Composite may find itself tossed about in rougher seas. (Full Story)


(Terence Gabriel)

*****

(Terence Gabriel is a Reuters market analyst. The views expressed are his own)
